The files will then be copied to your machine (you will see a row of filenames, preceeded by the letter A).

section.title: Building, compiling and running
section.p: When everything is checked out and residing on your computer, you probably want to compile and run our linguistic analysers. For this you need to install the required tools. They are:

ul.li: Xerox morphological transducer tools, for morphological analysis. This is proprietary software, and not available for download, but it is included with the book Finite State Morphology by Kenneth R. Beesley and Lauri Karttunen. The book has its own home page. Unfortunately we do not have an open source alternative for compiling our morphological analysers, basically because there are none compatible with our source, and almost none able to handle Sámi in a decent way. One possible open-source alternative would be SFST, but it would require major reworking of our lexicons, and a lot of other work as well.

vislcg, for disambiguation. This is open source, but has no documentation accompanying the software (there are references to external/printed documentation). We have written instructions on how to compile and and use vislcg3.

section.p: Other tools (perl scripts, shell scripts, etc.) should have been included in the SVN check-out, but might require some environment setups (PATHs etc). See our technical documentation and the subsection in the corresponding menu.

section.title: Reading the documentation off-line
section.p: The full documentation is available online on divvun.no, but if you want to read the documentation off-line, you are best off installing and running Forrest. You will find it at our server.
We have made a document on how to install and use forrest, follow the instructions there on how to use forrest on your private machine

section.title: Sending feedback and patches
section.p: If you have improvements to our code, be it linguistic corrections, C-code bug fixes, documentation enhancements or whatever, we would welcome your contribution. Please make a cvs diff, gzip it, and send it to us.
section.warning: This e-mail address may change in the future!

section.title: Interactive feedback and discussions
section.p: The whole team is available on AIM, and we frequently keep discussions through our favourite AIM client(s). Our AIM addresses can be found on our contact page.

We also use SubEthaEdit (SEE) a lot to do collaborative development, but SEE is Mac only, and commercial (version 2.2 is available for free for non-commercial purposes). A cross-platform alternative is Gobby (please see the installation notes, especially Mac users - the Mac version only installs through DarwinPorts). Try it, or SEE - realtime collaborative development is both very fun and productive, and creates a whole new feeling of working together, even when sitting in different countries! Much of what we have done would have taken 10 x the time, or not been possible at all without SEE.

If you have questions or problems, either e-mail us, or start a chat. Further investigation can be done collaboratively and interactively using SEE or Gobby. If you are using a Mac with a recent OS version (10.4.x, aka Tiger), you can even invite us to (group) voice or video chats using iChat. Non-group voice and video chats should also work with earlier versions of MacOS, as well as with a recent version of the AIM client for Windows (we haven't tried voice or video chats with Windows users).
